Issues.Title: Simplify the tooltip state machine
Issues.Body:
The dictionary of delegates isn't needed for this state machine's decision making. This improves perf and removes allocations from form startup.

Add some basic tests for hooking. Can't exercise the entire state machine in unit tests as it will fire timers and UI.

Issues.Title: Use version check to gate features
Issues.Body:
Poking at dlls directly to try and find apis is expensive. RtlGetVersion doesn't lie or require a manifest on user apps. Add `OsVersion` helper to gate calls to APIs that have a specific OS version requirement.

Issues.Title: Consider using reflection to optimize code paths in stock scenarios
Issues.Body:
WinForms is almost completely configurable but that comes at a performance cost. When we get windows messages (`WM_*`) we create event classes and jump through a lot of hoops that would not be necessary in a closed system.

For one example, getting a `WM_ERASEBKGND` often ends up being a `FillRect` on the passed in `HDC`.  We could potentially avoid a lot of hoop jumping some allocations if we knew the `OnPaintBackground` was completely under our control.

We would pay up front for this sort of check, but could potentially earn it back quite quickly. The following code takes a couple of milliseconds on class creation:

``` C#
Type type = GetType();
_isTypeInAssembly = type.Assembly == typeof(Control).Assembly;

_isOnPaintBackgroundLocal = _isTypeInAssembly
    || type.GetMethod(
        "OnPaintBackground",
        BindingFlags.NonPublic | BindingFlags.Instance,
        null,
        new Type[] { typeof(PaintEventArgs) }, null
             ).DeclaringType.Assembly == typeof(Control).Assembly;
```

If we find measurable situations where we go "if only we knew this wasn't customized" this may be a strategy to attempt.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Consider using reflection to optimize code paths in stock scenarios" (#1441)

Existing open source projects

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/cpp/mfc/ribbon-designer-mfc?view=vs-2019

So, I think winforms should have Ribbon.

Issues.Title: fixing tests broken in VS only
Issues.Body:
Fixes tests broken in VS only. Assert.Same does not work in VS because xUnit MemberData is populated in a different AppDomain, which means the references are not equal.

Assert.Equal should be used for string compares anyway 😉

Issues.Title: Fixing code style to avoid build fail
Issues.Body:
## Proposed changes

- Made `service.GetTestAccessor()` construction as separate variable. This will avoid the build fail and excessive calls to `GetTestAccessor()` method.

## Before

After pulling master branch project build is fail for the reason that the compiler can't recognize `GetTestAccessor()` method.

### Screenshots 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/49272759/61541005-70993700-aa47-11e9-89a8-5caa60df70a0.png)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/49272759/61540992-6b3bec80-aa47-11e9-9f5a-c861e5bfc038.png)

## After

Project build is successful

## Test environment(s) 

- Microsoft Windows [Version 10.0.18362.175]
- .NET Core SDK. Version: 3.0.0-preview8-27916-13

###### Microsoft Reviewers: [Open in CodeFlow](http://wpcp.azurewebsites.net/CodeFlowProtocolProxy2.php?pullrequest=https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/1428)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "Fixing code style to avoid build fail" (#1428)

Issues.Title: [WIP] Removing or annotating Serializable attribute on winforms classes
Issues.Body:
Fixes #889, #890 
These changes are built upon #1236
I decided to start a new PR because one of the feedback items was to factor out cleanup changes.
Changes on top of #1236
1. updated comments per feedback
2. edited the test to cover a single assembly
3. add serializable attribute test to other assemblies
4. annotate structs that are known to be used in resx serialization

Coming soon:
1. add round trip tests for classes
2. see if any more integration tests would make sense

Issues.Title: Fix 1423 Accessibility: The ToolStrip control UIA hierarchy of PrintPreviewDialog is not correct
Issues.Body:
<!-- Please read CONTRIBUTING.md before submitting a pull request -->

Fixes #1423 


## Proposed changes

- Refactoring the ToolStripControlHost accessibility provider to make it reusable by derivates.
- Implement UIA Accessibility provider for ToolStrip-hosted NumericUpDown control and its host Too;Strip item.
- Rework other ToolStrip-hosted controls' accessibility where this is possible and safe.


## Screenshots <!-- Remove this section if PR does not change UI -->

### Before

Please see #1423 
- Incorrect position of spinner control in accessible hierarchy (should be the last element)
- Infinite loop of UIA elements (children of ToolStrip)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23213980/61470488-de7f2900-a989-11e9-8752-800f7d74d370.png)


### After

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23213980/61470891-77ae3f80-a98a-11e9-9c90-3618ea47a840.png)


## Test methodology <!-- How did you ensure quality? -->

- Manual testing
- Accessibility tools (Inspect, Narrator)
- UIA hierarchy shoul

## Accessibility testing  <!-- Remove this section if PR does not change UI -->

- Without the change the accessible hierarchy of ToolStrip control in the PrintPreviewDialog is incorrect: Spinner control has incorrect position (first instead of last) and the collection of UIA elements is endless due to the loop between the first and the last element.

- With the change available accessible hierarchy is correct: spinner is the last child of ToolStrip, there is no infinite loop of ToolStrip children.

<!--
     Microsoft prioritizes making our products accessible. 
     WinForms has a key role in allowing developers to create accessible apps. 
     
     When submitting a change which impacts UI in any way, including adding new UI or
     modifying existing controls the developer needs to run the Accessibility Insights
     tool (https://accessibilityinsights.io/) and verify that there are no changes or
     regressions. 
     
     The developer should run the Fast Pass over the impacted control(s) and provide
     a snapshot of the passing results along with before/after snapshots of the UI.
     More info: (https://accessibilityinsights.io/docs/en/web/getstarted/fastpass)
  -->


 

## Test environment(s) <!-- Remove any that don't apply -->

.NET Core SDK (reflecting any global.json):
Version: 3.0.100-preview8-012929
Commit: 795f8aeaa8
Runtime Environment:
OS Name: Windows
OS Version: 10.0.18362
OS Platform: Windows
RID: win10-x64
Base Path: C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk\3.0.100-preview8-012929\



<!-- Mention language, UI scaling, or anything else that might be relevant -->

Issues.Title: Accessibility: The ToolStrip control UIA hierarchy of PrintPreviewDialog is not correct
Issues.Body:
Accessibility hierarchy of the PrintPreviewDialog's ToolStrip is not correct and may freeze the Inspect/other accessibility client app (due to infinite loop of UIA child elements):

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23213980/61470137-31a4ac00-a989-11e9-92a4-a1ce93f6c984.png)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Accessibility: The ToolStrip control UIA hierarchy of PrintPreviewDialog is not correct" (#1423)

Issues.Title: Accessibility: [High Contrast]: The text cannot be shown when focus "Close" button of ToolStrip item in Print Preview dialog
Issues.Body:
* .NET Core Version: 3.0.100 Preview8 13316 from master branch
* Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: Yes.

**Repro Steps:**

1. Open control panel and select the respective high contrast theme.
2. Open the attached application [PrintDemo .zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/3405539/PrintDemo.zip), build and run. 
3. Click the 'Preview' button to show the Print preview dialog then focus on ‘Close’ button.

**Actual:**
The text cannot be shown when focus "Close" button of 'Print Preview' dialog on the Black and White theme. See following screenshot for Black and White theme.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/45864649/61443867-e71d3280-a97c-11e9-9dca-ba72ff67e889.png)

**Expected:**
The text should be shown when focus "Close" button of 'Print Preview' dialog on the Black and White theme. See following screenshot for # 1 and # 2 theme.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/45864649/61444150-6a3e8880-a97d-11e9-88b0-23d83b6f178f.png)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Accessibility: [High Contrast]: The text cannot be shown when focus "Close" button of ToolStrip item in Print Preview dialog" (#1421)
